utterances.content: and I haven't had as much time for painting and drawing as I like because it gets time consuming and you hafta have the space to do it in

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: last October I sent in a poem to a contest

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and it was in the top three percent

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and two others from two different contests are being published too

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: so I don't know some of those people that said I had no verbal skills were wrong

utterances.speaker: INV
utterances.content: what kind of poem do you write

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: um about the way life is

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and like the poem that won was the one I wrote when Firstname_Lastname died

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: do you remember him from our department

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: when he died everybody was just completely shaken up

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and I wrote a poem and gave it to his wife

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and I had a copy of it

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and I figured that'd be a good one to send in because more people would understand it

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I write in rather abstract terms

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: like if I were going to talk about your computer I wouldn't say computer

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I'd say something that represented a computer

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and unless you know me moderately well or you are good with uh parallels and stuff there's you're gonna miss it

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I_mean there's a surface meaning you'll get sure

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: but you won't get one of the two or three multi underlying themes

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: you know it talks about a tree growing in the forest

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: fine tree does grow in the forest

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: but what does that tree represent

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: it represents maybe the struggle of man who find himself and you_know having his ban branches trimmed or society's pressures on him you_know and being chopped down by the logger or something you_know

utterances.speaker: INV
utterances.content: you know I have never uh attempted writing poetry

utterances.speaker: INV
utterances.content: but it just seems very difficult

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: well yeah I'm not in structured form

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I do free verse which means that nothing hasta rhyme

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and it's just as long as the thought is coherent throughout it that's fine

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: that's all it needs to have

utterances.speaker: INV
utterances.content: now when did you start writing poetry

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: uh twelve or thirteen years old

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: my older brother said that I had a_lot_of crazy thoughts or wild thoughts and write it down

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: you know when guys go through that macho phase at about thirteen or fourteen they're like

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: yeah well what about this musician and that musician and that musician

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: like Morrison and Bob_Dylan and most musicians even today in some form are poets because they're putting their words to music

utterances.speaker: INV
utterances.content: now uh do you like music

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: oh yeah it's one of my big hobbies

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I trade cassettes with people from all over the country and

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and you send it to them

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and you meet them through either going to the concerts and just happening to bump into them or certain magazines like fan magazines put out by whichever band you like like have personals

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: will trade with you for dadadada

utterances.speaker: INV
utterances.content: uh now are these bootleg tapes

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: um certain bands are what people would consider bootlegs yes

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: but I_mean some band like Grateful_Dead and a few others allow ta people to tape

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: they actually have a section dedicated to it

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: instead of paying twenty dollars for a regular ticket you pay thirty thirty five and get to sit in that section

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and whatever you can haul in and set up you can use

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I think the equipment would be far more expensive

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I even think that as unique as that may look that isn't even in the realm that they have

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I'm talking like one of the women I trade tapes with

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: tra she goes to shows with this guy

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and he has like a seven hundred dollar mic

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and he has two little three hundred dollar mics on the side

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: so it gets a better dynamic range

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and he runs it through like a little equalizer

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and that's like five hundred dollars

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: you know carrying like seven hundred i in equipment just in mics

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: you know couple thousand in your trunk yeah

utterances.content: and I sat there and said

utterances.content: and I sat across from her and started talking

utterances.content: five years eight months later here we are

utterances.content: so is she a pretty good artist

utterances.content: she's got a wider variety of art work

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: but I do mostly print making and don't do a_lot_of painting and more hand drawing

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and she's done jewelry and glass blowing and ceramics and uh graphics and the painting and the sculpturing

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: so I think she's got a better eclectic ability

utterances.content: and her painting skills are better than mine we've done paintings for wedding gifts for people

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: and I think where I'll start something she can copy my style my brush strokes and which is very hard with me being left handed and her being right handed to get the same sort of angles and the same sort of rhythm coming

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: I don't know if you can picture that

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: it would be like if you tried to copy someone who was right handed or left handed when they wrote

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: uh yeah it makes it diffi more difficult to paint but easier because like where my strengths are in painting her weaknesses are

utterances.speaker: PAR
utterances.content: where I'll sit there and look at the sky and we did uh a forest and a mountain in winter from a calendar which made it easier

utterances.speaker: PAR
